analyzed: nidhāya hṛdi viśveśam vidhāya guru vandanam
translated: Having placed the Lord of the universe in the heart and having paid homage to the teacher,

analyzed: bālānām sukha bodhāya kriyate tarka saṃgrahaḥ
translated: The Tattva-samgraha is composed for the easy understanding of the young.

analyzed: dravya guṇa karma sāmānya viśeṣa samavāya abhāvāḥ sapta padārthāḥ
translated: The seven categories are substance, quality, action, universality, particularity, inherence, and non-existence.

analyzed: tatra dravyāṇi pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśa kāla diś ātma manāṃsi nava eva  rūpa rasa gandha sparśa saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva guru tva drava tva sneha śabda buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma adharma saṃskārāḥ
translated: Among them, the substances are only nine: earth, water, fire, air, space, time, direction, self, and mind.

analyzed: caturviṃśati guṇāḥ
translated: The twenty-four qualities are color, taste, smell, touch, number, measure, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, heaviness, fluidity, viscidity, sound, cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, merit, demerit, and latent impressions.

analyzed: utkṣepaṇa avakṣepaṇa ākuñcana prasāraṇa gamanāni pañca karmāṇi
translated: The five actions are throwing upwards, throwing downwards, contraction, expansion, and motion.

analyzed: param aparam ca iti dvividham sāmānyam
translated: Universality is of two kinds: supreme and inferior.

analyzed: nitya dravya vṛttayaḥ viśeṣāḥ tu anantāḥ eva
translated: The particularities are infinite, occurring in eternal substances.

analyzed: ants samavāyaḥ tu ekaḥ eva
translated: Inherence is only one.

analyzed: ants abhāvaḥ caturvidhaḥ
translated: Non-existence is of four kinds.

analyzed: prāgabhāvaḥ tyanta abhāvaḥ nyonya abhāvaḥ ca iti
translated: Prior non-existence, post-destruction non-existence, absolute non-existence, and mutual non-existence.

analyzed: gandhavatī pṛthivī
translated: Earth has smell.

analyzed: sā dvividhā nityā anityā ca
translated: It is of two kinds: eternal and non-eternal.

analyzed: nityā paramāṇu rūpā
translated: The eternal one is atomic in form.

analyzed: anityā kārya rūpā
translated: The non-eternal one is in the form of an effect.

analyzed: punar trividhā śarīra indriya viṣaya bhedāt
translated: It is again of three kinds, due to the difference of body, sense organ, and object.

analyzed: śarīram asmat ādīnām
translated: The body is of us and others.

analyzed: indriyam gandha grāhakam ghrāṇam nāsā agra varti
translated: The sense organ that perceives smell is the nose, located at the tip of the nose.

analyzed: viṣayaḥ mṛd pāṣāṇa ādiḥ
translated: The object is earth, stone, etc.

analyzed: śita sparśavatyaḥ āpaḥ
translated: Water has the quality of coolness.

analyzed: tāḥ dvividhāḥ nityāḥ anityāḥ ca
translated: It is of two kinds: eternal and non-eternal.

analyzed: ntyāḥ paramāṇu rūpāḥ
translated: The eternal one is atomic in form.

analyzed: anityāḥ kārya rūpāḥ
translated: The non-eternal one is in the form of an effect.

analyzed: punar trividhāḥ śarīra indriya viṣaya bhedāt
translated: It is again of three kinds, due to the difference of body, sense organ, and object.

analyzed: śarīram varuṇa loke
translated: The body is in the world of Varuna.

analyzed: indriyam rasa grāhakam rasanam jihvā agra varti
translated: The sense organ that perceives taste is the tongue, located at the tip of the tongue.

analyzed: viṣayaḥ sarit samudra ādiḥ
translated: The object is rivers, oceans, etc.

analyzed: uṣṇa sparśavat tejaḥ
translated: Fire has the quality of heat.

analyzed: tat dvividham nityam anityam ca
translated: It is of two kinds: eternal and non-eternal.

analyzed: paramāṇu rūpam
translated: The eternal one is atomic in form.

analyzed: anityam kārya rūpam
translated: The non-eternal one is in the form of an effect.

analyzed: punar trividham śarīra indriya viṣaya bhedāt
translated: It is again of three kinds, due to the difference of body, sense organ, and object.

analyzed: śarīram āditya loke
translated: The body is in the world of the sun.

analyzed: indriyam rūpa grāhakam cakṣuḥ kṛṣṇa tārā agra varti
translated: The sense organ that perceives form is the eye, located at the tip of the black pupil.

analyzed: viṣayaḥ caturvidhaḥ
translated: The object is of four kinds.

analyzed: bhauma divya audarya ākara ja bhedāt
translated: Due to the difference of being on earth, in the sky, in the stomach, and being produced from a mine.

analyzed: bhaumam vahni ādikam
translated: The earthly one is fire and so on.

original: abindhanaṃ divyaṃ vidyudādi /🔽bhuktasya pariṇāmahetur audaryam / ākarajaṃ suvarṇādi //
analyzed: abindhanam divyam vidyut ādi  bhuktasya pariṇāma hetuḥ audaryam ākara jam suvarṇa ādi
translated: The divine [air] without fuel is lightning, etc.🔽The internal [air] is the cause of the digestion of what is eaten. The [air] from a source is gold, etc.

analyzed: rūpa rahita sparśavān vāyuḥ
translated: Air has touch but not color.

analyzed: sa dvividhaḥ nityaḥ nityaḥ ca
translated: It is of two kinds: eternal and non-eternal.

analyzed: nityaḥ paramāṇu rūpaḥ
translated: The eternal is of atomic form.

analyzed: anityaḥ kārya rūpaḥ
translated: The non-eternal is of produced form.

analyzed: punar trividhaḥ śarīra indriya viṣaya bhedāt
translated: Again, it is of three kinds, due to the difference of body, sense organ, and object.

analyzed: śarīram vāyu loke
translated: The body is in the world of air.

analyzed: indriyam sparśa grāhakam tvac sarva śarīra varti
translated: The sense organ, which perceives touch, pervades the entire body.

analyzed: viṣayaḥ vṛkṣa ādi kampana hetuḥ
translated: The object is the cause of the shaking of trees, etc.

analyzed: śarīra antar saṃcārī vāyuḥ prāṇaḥ
translated: The air that moves inside the body is the life-breath.

analyzed: sa ca ekaḥ pi upādhi bhedāt prāṇa apāna ādi saṃjñāḥ labhate
translated: And that [air], although one, gets the names prana, apana, etc., due to the difference of limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: śabda guṇam ākāśam
translated: Space has the quality of sound.

analyzed: tat ca ekam vibhu nityam ca
translated: And that is one, all-pervading, and eternal.
Time is the cause of the usage of past, etc.

analyzed: sa ca ekaḥ vibhuḥ nityaḥ ca
translated: And that is one, all-pervading, and eternal.
Direction is the cause of the usage of east, etc.

analyzed: sā ca ekā vibhvī nityā ca
translated: And that is one, all-pervading, and eternal.

analyzed: jñāna adhikaraṇam ātmā
translated: The self is the substratum of knowledge.

analyzed: sa dvividhaḥ paramātmā jīvātmā ca
translated: It is of two kinds: the supreme self and the individual self.

analyzed: tatra īśvaraḥ sarvajñaḥ paramātmā ekaḥ eva
translated: There, the omniscient Lord is the supreme self alone.

original: jīvātmā pratiśarīraṃ bhinno vibhur nityaś ca //
analyzed: jīvātmā pratiśarīram bhinnaḥ vibhuḥ nityaḥ ca
translated: The individual soul is different for each body, all-pervading, and eternal.
The sense organ is the means of perceiving pleasure etc. and the mind.

original: tac ca pratyātmaniyatatvād anantaṃ paramāṇurūpaṃ nityaṃ ca //
analyzed: tat ca pratyātma niyata tvāt anantam paramāṇu rūpam nityam ca
translated: And that is infinite, atomic in form, and eternal, because it is restricted to each individual self.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ mātra grāhyaḥ guṇaḥ rūpam
translated: The quality that is perceptible only by the eye is form.

analyzed: tat ca śukla nīla pīta rakta harita kapiśa citra bhedāt saptavidham pṛthivī jala tejaḥ vṛtti
translated: And that is of seven kinds, being divided into white, blue, yellow, red, green, tawny, and variegated, and it exists in earth, water, and fire.

analyzed: tatra pṛthivyām saptavidham  abhāsvara śuklam jale
translated: Of these, in earth it is of seven kinds.🔽In water it is non-luminous white.

analyzed: bhāsvara śuklam tejasi
translated: In fire it is luminous white.
The quality that is perceptible by the tongue is taste.

analyzed: sa ca madhura amla lavaṇa kaṭu kaṣāya tikta bhedāt ṣaḍvidhaḥ
translated: And that is of six kinds, being divided into sweet, sour, salty, pungent, astringent, and bitter.

analyzed: pṛthivyām ṣaḍvidhaḥ
translated: In earth it is of six kinds.

analyzed: jale madhuraḥ eva
translated: In water it is sweet alone.

analyzed: ghrāṇa grāhyaḥ guṇaḥ gandhaḥ
translated: The quality that is perceptible by the nose is smell.

analyzed: sa ca dvividhaḥ surabhiḥ asurabhiḥ ca
translated: And that is of two kinds, fragrant and foul-smelling.
It exists only in earth.

analyzed: tvac indriya mātra grāhyaḥ guṇaḥ sa parśaḥ
translated: The quality that is perceptible only by the skin sense organ is touch.

analyzed: sa ca trividhaḥ śita uṣṇa anuṣṇa aśīta bhedāt
translated: And that is of three kinds, being divided into cold, hot, and neither hot nor cold.
It exists in earth, water, fire, and air.

analyzed: tatra śītaḥ jale
translated: Of these, cold is in water.

analyzed: uṣṇaḥ tejasi
translated: Hot is in fire.

analyzed: an uṣṇa aśītaḥ pṛthivī vāyvoḥ
translated: Heat and cold belong to earth and air.

analyzed: rūpa ādi catuṣṭayam pṛthivyām pāka jam anityam ca
translated: The four beginning with color in earth are produced by cooking and impermanent.

analyzed: anyatra apāka jam nityam antyam ca
translated: Elsewhere they are not produced by cooking, permanent, and the last.

analyzed: nitya gatam nityam
translated: That which belongs to the permanent is permanent.

analyzed: anitya gatam anityam
translated: That which belongs to the impermanent is impermanent.

analyzed: eka tva ādi vyavahāra hetuḥ saṃkhyā
translated: Number is the cause of the usage of oneness, etc.
It occurs in nine substances, from oneness up to the highest number.

analyzed: eka tvam nityam anityam ca
translated: Oneness is permanent and impermanent.

analyzed: nitya gatam nityam anitya gatam anityam
translated: That which belongs to the permanent is permanent, that which belongs to the impermanent is impermanent.

analyzed: dvi tva ādikam tu sarvatra anityam eva
translated: But twoness, etc. are everywhere impermanent.

analyzed: māna vyavahāra kāraṇam parimāṇam
translated: Dimension is the cause of the usage of large, small, etc.

analyzed: nava dravya vṛtti
translated: It occurs in nine substances.

analyzed: tat caturvidham
translated: And it is of four kinds:

analyzed: aṇu mahat dīrgham hrasvam ca iti
translated: atomic, gross, long, and short.
Separateness is the cause of the usage of separate.

analyzed: sarva dravya vṛtti
translated: It occurs in all substances.

analyzed: saṃyukta vyavahāra hetuḥ saṃyogaḥ
translated: Conjunction is the cause of the usage of conjoined.

analyzed: sarva dravya vṛttiḥ
translated: It occurs in all substances.

analyzed: saṃyoga nāśakaḥ guṇaḥ vibhāgaḥ
translated: The quality that destroys conjunction is disjunction.

analyzed: sarva dravya vṛttiḥ
translated: It occurs in all substances.
Superiority and inferiority are the uncommon causes of the usage of higher and lower.

analyzed: pṛthivī ādi catuṣṭaya manaḥ vṛtti iti
translated: They occur in the four beginning with earth and in the mind.

analyzed: te dvividhe diś kṛte kāla kṛte ca
translated: They are of two kinds: produced by space and produced by time.

analyzed: dūra sthe diś kṛtam para tvam
translated: When far away, the priority is due to direction.

analyzed: samīpa sthe diś kṛtam apara tvam  jyeṣṭhe kālakṛtham paratvam
translated: When near, the posteriority is due to direction.🔽In the elder, the priority is due to time.

analyzed: kaniṣṭhe kāla kṛtam aparatvam
translated: In the younger, the posteriority is due to time.

analyzed: ādya patana asamavāyi kāraṇam guru tvam
translated: The non-inherent cause of the first fall is gravity.
It exists in earth and water.

analyzed: ādya syandana asamavāyi kāraṇam drava tvam pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vṛtti
translated: The non-inherent cause of the first fluidity is fluidity, which exists in earth, water, and fire.

original: tad dvividhaṃ sāṃsiddhikaṃ naimittikaṃ ca /🔽sāṃsiddhikaṃ jale naimittikaṃ pṛthivītejasoḥ /
analyzed: tat dvividham sāṃsiddhikam naimittikam ca  sāṃsiddhikam jale naimittikam pṛthivī tejasoḥ
translated: It is of two kinds: natural and accidental.🔽Natural fluidity is in water, accidental fluidity is in earth and fire.
In earth, fluidity is produced by contact with fire, as in ghee.

analyzed: tejasi suvarṇa ādau
translated: In fire, as in gold.
The quality that causes the aggregation of dust particles is oiliness.
It exists only in water.

analyzed: śrotra grāhyaḥ guṇaḥ śabdaḥ
translated: The quality that is grasped by the auditory sense is sound.

analyzed: ākāśa mātra vṛttiḥ  sa dvividhaḥ dvanya ātmakaḥ varṇa ātmakaḥ ca iti
translated: It exists only in space.🔽It is of two kinds: consisting of noise and consisting of letters.

analyzed: dvanya ātmakaḥ bherī ādau
translated: The sound consisting of noise is in a drum, etc.

analyzed: varṇa ātmakaḥ saṃskṛta bhāṣā ādi rūpaḥ
translated: The sound consisting of letters is in the form of cultured language, etc.

analyzed: sarva vyavahāra hetuḥ buddhiḥ jñānam
translated: The cause of all transactions is cognition, knowledge.

analyzed: sā dvividhā smṛtiḥ anubhavaḥ ca
translated: It is of two kinds: memory and experience.
Knowledge produced solely by impressions is memory.

original: tadbhinnaṃ jñānam anubhavaḥ //🔽sa dvividho yathārtho 'yathārthaś ca /
analyzed: tad bhinnam jñānam anubhavaḥ  sa dvividhaḥ yathārthaḥ yathārthaḥ ca
translated: Knowledge that is different from that is experience.🔽It is of two kinds: true and false.

analyzed: tadvati tad prakārakaḥ nubhavaḥ yathā arthaḥ
translated: An experience that has the form of an object and is about an object that exists is true.

original: yathā rajata idaṃ rajatam iti jñānam /
analyzed: yathā rajate idam rajatam iti jñānam
translated: For example, the knowledge that this is silver when there is silver.

analyzed: saḥ eva pramā iti ucyate
translated: That is called valid knowledge.

analyzed: tad abhāvavati tad prakārakaḥ nubhavaḥ yathārthaḥ
translated: An experience that has the form of an object and is about an object that does not exist is false.

original: yathā śuktāv idaṃ rajatam iti jñānam //🔽yathārthānubhavaś caturvidhaḥ pratyakṣānumityupamitiśabdabhedāt /
analyzed: yathā śuktau idam rajatam iti jñānam
translated: For example, the knowledge that this is silver when there are mother-of-pearl shells.🔽True experience is of four kinds, distinguished as perception, inference, analogy, and verbal testimony.

analyzed: tad karaṇam api caturvidham pratyakṣa anumāna upamāna śabda bhedāt
translated: The instruments of knowledge are also of four kinds, distinguished as perception, inference, analogy, and verbal testimony.

analyzed: asādhāraṇam kāraṇam karaṇam
translated: An instrument is a cause that is not shared.🔽A cause is that which precedes its effect and is restricted to it.
An effect is that which is opposed to prior non-existence.

analyzed: kāraṇam trividham samavāyi asamavāyi nimitta bhedāt
translated: A cause is of three kinds, distinguished as inhering, non-inhering, and instrumental.

original: yat samavetaṃ kāryam utpadyate tat samavāyikāraṇam /
analyzed: yat samavetam kāryam utpadyate tat samavāyi kāraṇam
translated: That which is an effect that arises as an inherence is an inhering cause.

original: yathā tantavaḥ paṭasya paṭaś ca khagatarūpādeḥ /
analyzed: yathā tantavaḥ paṭasya paṭaḥ ca kha gata rūpa ādeḥ
translated: For example, threads are an inhering cause of a cloth, and a cloth is an inhering cause of the color, etc. in the cloth.

original: kāryeṇa kāraṇena vā sahaikasminn arthe samavetatve sati yat kāraṇaṃ tad asamavāyikāraṇam /
analyzed: kāryeṇa kāraṇena vā saha ekasmin arthe samaveta tve sati yat kāraṇam tat asamavāyikāraṇam
translated: When something inheres in the same object as either the effect or the cause, that cause is the inherent cause.

analyzed: yathā tantu saṃyogaḥ paṭasya tantu rūpam paṭa rūpasya
translated: For example, the conjunction of threads is the inherent cause of the cloth, and the color of the threads is the inherent cause of the color of the cloth.

analyzed: tad ubhaya bhinnam kāraṇam nimitta kāraṇam
translated: A cause that is different from both of those is the non-inherent cause.

analyzed: yathā turī vema ādikam paṭasya
translated: For example, the shuttle, loom, etc. are the non-inherent causes of the cloth.

original: tad etattrividhakāraṇamadhye yad asādhāraṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ tad eva karaṇam //
analyzed: tat etat trividha kāraṇa madhye yat asādhāraṇam kāraṇam tat eva karaṇam
translated: Among these three types of causes, that which is the uncommon cause is itself the instrument.

analyzed: tatra pratyakṣa jñāna karaṇam pratyakṣam
translated: Among them, perception is the instrument of perceptual knowledge.

analyzed: indriya artha sannikarṣa janyam jñānam pratyakṣam
translated: Perceptual knowledge is that which arises from the contact of sense and object.

analyzed: tat dvividham nirvikalpakam savikalpakam ca iti
translated: It is of two kinds: non-conceptual and conceptual.

original: tatra nirvikalpakaṃ jñānaṃ nirvikalpakaṃ yathedaṃ kiṃcit /
analyzed: tatra nirvikalpakam jñānam nirvikalpakam yathā idam kiṃcid
translated: Among them, non-conceptual knowledge is non-conceptual, like this is something.

original: saparakārakaṃ jñānaṃ savikalpakaṃ yathā ḍittho'yam brahmaṇo'yaṃ śyāmo'yam iti //
analyzed: sa para kārakam jñānam sa vikalpakam yathā iti
translated: Knowledge with a specific operation is conceptual, like this is Dittha, this belongs to Brahma, this is dark.
The contact of sense and object, which is the cause of perceptual knowledge, is of six kinds.

original: saṃyogaḥ saṃyuktasamavāyaḥ saṃyuktasamavetasamavāyaḥ samavāyaḥ samavetasamavāyo viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaś ceti /
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ saṃyukta samavāyaḥ saṃyukta samaveta samavāyaḥ samavāyaḥ samaveta samavāyaḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ ca iti
translated: [The six kinds of relation are] contact, inherence in what is in contact, inherence in what inheres in what is in contact, inherence, inherence in what inheres, and the relation of qualifier and qualified.

original: cakṣuṣā ghaṭapratyakṣajanane saṃyogaḥ sannikarṣaḥ /🔽ghaṭarūpapratyakṣajanane saṃyuktasamavāyaḥ sannikarṣaḥ cakṣuḥsaṃyukte ghaṭe rūpasya samavāyāt /
analyzed: cakṣuṣā ghaṭa pratyakṣa janane saṃyogaḥ sannikarṣaḥ  ghaṭa rūpa pratyakṣa janane saṃyukta samavāyaḥ sannikarṣaḥ cakṣuḥ saṃyukte ghaṭe rūpasya samavāyāt
translated: In the production of the perception of a pot by the eye, contact is the relation.🔽In the production of the perception of the color of the pot, the relation is inherence in what is in contact, because color inheres in the pot which is in contact with the eye.

original: rūpatvasāmānyapratyakṣe saṃyuktasamavetasamavāyaḥ sannikarṣaḥ cakṣuḥsaṃyukte ghaṭe rūpaṃ samavetaṃ tatra rūpatvasya samavāyāt /
analyzed: rūpa tva sāmānya pratyakṣe saṃyukta samaveta samavāyaḥ sannikarṣaḥ cakṣuḥ saṃyukte ghaṭe rūpam samavetam tatra rūpa tvasya samavāyāt
translated: In the perception of the universal color, the relation is inherence in what inheres in what is in contact, because color inheres in the pot which is in contact with the eye.

analyzed: śrotreṇa śabdasya ākāśa guṇa tvāt guṇa guṇinoḥ ca samavāyāt
translated: In the case of sound, since sound is a quality of space, and there is inherence between a quality and its substrate,

original: śabdatvasākṣātkāre samavetasamavāyaḥ sannikarṣaḥ śrotrasamavete śabde śabdatvasya samavāyāt /
analyzed: śabda tva sākṣātkāre samaveta samavāyaḥ sannikarṣaḥ śrotra samavete śabde śabda tvasya samavāyāt
translated: in the direct awareness of the universal soundness, the relation is inherence in what inheres, because soundness inheres in the sound which inheres in the ear.

analyzed: abhāva para tyakṣe viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ sannikarṣaḥ ghaṭa abhāva vat
translated: In the perception of absence, the relation is that of qualifier and qualified, as in the statement the ground devoid of pot

original: bhṛtalam ity atra cakṣuḥsaṃyukte bhūtale ghaṭābhāvasya viśeṣaṇatvāt /
analyzed: bhṛ talam iti atra cakṣuḥ saṃyukte bhū tale ghaṭa abhāvasya viśeṣaṇa tvāt
translated: where the absence of pot is the qualifier in the ground which is in contact with the eye.

analyzed: evam snnikarṣa ṣaṭka janyam jñānam pratyakṣam
translated: Thus, perception is the knowledge produced by the sixfold contact.

analyzed: tad karaṇam indriyam
translated: The sense organ is the instrument of that.

analyzed: tasmāt indriyam pratyakṣa pramāṇam iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that the sense organ is the means of valid knowledge of perception.

analyzed: anumiti karaṇam anumānam
translated: An inference is that which produces inference.

analyzed: vyāpti viśiṣṭa pakṣa dharma tā jñānam parāmarśaḥ
translated: Inference is the knowledge produced by a mark.🔽A mark is the knowledge of the subject qualified by the pervasion.

original: yathā vahnivyāpyadhūmavān ayaṃ parvata iti jñānaṃ parāmarśaḥ /
analyzed: yathā vahni vyāpya dhūmavān ayam parvataḥ iti jñānam parāmarśaḥ
translated: For example, the knowledge that this mountain has smoke which is pervaded by fire is a mark.

original: taj janyaṃ parvato vahnimān iti jñānam anumitiḥ /🔽yatra yatra dhūmas tatrāgnir iti sāhacaryaniyamo vyāptiḥ /
analyzed: tat janyam parvataḥ vahnimān iti jñānam anumitiḥ  yatra yatra dhūmaḥ tatra agniḥ iti sāhacarya niyamaḥ vyāptiḥ
translated: The knowledge that the mountain has fire, which is produced by that, is an inference.🔽The rule of concomitance, that wherever there is smoke there is fire, is the pervasion.

analyzed: vyāpyasya parvata ādi vṛtti tvam pakṣa dharma tā
translated: The fact that the pervaded occurs in the subject like a mountain is the subject property.

analyzed: anumānam dvividham sva artham para artham ca
translated: Inference is of two kinds: for one's own sake and for the sake of others.

analyzed: tatra sva artham sva anumiti hetuḥ
translated: Among them, that for one's own sake is the cause of one's own inference.

original: tathā hi svayam eva bhūyo darśanena yatra dhūmas tatra agnir iti mahānasādau vyāptiṃ
analyzed: tathā hi svayam eva bhūyas darśanena yatra dhūmaḥ tatra agniḥ iti mahānasa ādau vyāptim
translated: For example, by oneself, through repeated observation, having grasped the pervasion that wherever there is smoke there is fire in a kitchen,

original: gṛhītvā parvatasamīpaṃ gatas tadgate cāgnau sandihānaḥ parvate dhūmaṃ paśyan vyāptiṃ
analyzed: gṛhītvā parvata samīpam gataḥ tad gate ca agnau sandihānaḥ parvate dhūmam paśyan vyāptim
translated: having gone near a mountain, and being doubtful about the fire there, seeing smoke on the mountain, one grasps the pervasion,

analyzed: smarati yatra dhūmaḥ tatra agniḥ iti
translated: It is like the memory that where there is smoke there is fire.

original: tadantaraṃ vahnivyāpyadhūmavān ayaṃ parvata iti jñānam utpadyate /
analyzed: tad antaram vahni vyāpya dhūmavān ayam parvataḥ iti jñānam utpadyate
translated: Then the knowledge arises that this mountain has smoke which is pervaded by fire.

analyzed: ayam eva liṅga parāmarṣam iti ucyate
translated: This is called the ascertainment of the inferential mark.

original: tasmāt parvato vahnimān iti jñānam anumitir utpadyate /
analyzed: tasmāt parvataḥ vahnimān iti jñānam anumitiḥ utpadyate
translated: From that, the knowledge arises that the mountain has fire, which is inference.

analyzed: tat etat sva artha anumānam
translated: This is inference for oneself.

original: yat tu svayaṃ dhūmād agnim anumāya parapratipattyarthaṃ pañcāvayavavākyaṃ prayukte tat parārthānumānam /
analyzed: yat tu svayam dhūmāt agnim anumāya para pratipatti artham pañca avayava vākyam prayukte tat para artha anumānam
translated: But when, after inferring fire from smoke oneself, one uses a five-membered sentence for the purpose of making others understand, that is inference for others.

analyzed: yathā parvataḥ vahnimān dhūmavat tvāt
translated: For example, The mountain has fire because it has smoke.

original: yo yo dhūmavān sa vahnimān yathā mahānasaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ yaḥ dhūmavān sa vahnimān yathā mahānasaḥ
translated: Whoever has smoke has fire, like a kitchen.

analyzed: tathā ca ayam
translated: And this [mountain] is like that.

analyzed: tasmāt tathā iti
translated: Therefore, it is so.

original: anena pratipāditāl lingāt paro'py agniṃ pratipadyate //
analyzed: anena pratipāditāt lingāt parā upi agnim pratipadyate
translated: By this, others also understand fire from the inferred mark.

analyzed: pratijñā hetu udāharaṇa upanaya nigamāni pañca avayavaḥ
translated: The five members are proposition, reason, example, application, and conclusion.

analyzed: parvataḥ vahnimān iti pratijñā
translated: The mountain has fire is the proposition.

analyzed: dhūmavat tvāt iti hetuḥ
translated: Because it has smoke is the reason.

original: yo yo dhūmavān sa so'gnimān yathā mahānasa ity udāharaṇam /
analyzed: yaḥ yaḥ dhūmavān sa sa agnimān yathā mahānasaḥ iti udāharaṇam
translated: Whoever has smoke has fire, like a kitchen is the example.

analyzed: tathā ca ayam iti upanayaḥ
translated: And this [mountain] is like that is the application.

analyzed: tasmāt tathā iti nigamanam
translated: Therefore, the conclusion is thus.

analyzed: sva artha anumiti para artha anumityoḥ liṅga parāmarśaḥ eva karaṇam
translated: In one's own inference and in inference for others, the cognition of the reason is the only instrument.

analyzed: tasmāt liṅga parāmarśa anumānam
translated: Therefore, inference is the cognition of the reason.

analyzed: anvaya vyatireki kevala anvayi kevala vyatireki ca iti
translated: The reason is of three kinds.🔽Positive-negative, purely positive, and purely negative.

original: anvayena vyatirekeṇa ca vyāptimad anvayavyatireki /🔽yathā vahnau sādhye dhūmavattvam /
analyzed: anvayena vyatirekeṇa ca vyāptimat anvaya vyatireki  yathā vahnau sādhye dhūmavat tvam
translated: The positive-negative reason is that which has pervasion by both positive and negative concomitance.🔽For example, in the case of fire being the probandum, the presence of smoke.

original: yatra dhūmas tatrāgnir yathā mahānasa ity anvayavyāptiḥ /
analyzed: yatra dhūmaḥ tatra agniḥ yathā mahānase iti anvaya vyāptiḥ
translated: The pervasion by positive concomitance is: where there is smoke, there is fire, like in a kitchen.

original: yatra vahnir nāsti tatra dhūmo'pi nāsti yathā mahāhrada iti vyatirekavyāptiḥ /
analyzed: yatra vahniḥ na asti tatra dhūmaḥ api na asti yathā mahā hradaḥ iti vyatireka vyāptiḥ
translated: The pervasion by negative concomitance is: where there is no fire, there is no smoke, like in a large lake.

original: anvayamātravyāptikaṃ kevalānvayi yathā ghaṭo'bhidheyaḥ prameyatvāt paṭavat /
analyzed: anvaya mātra vyāptikam kevala anvayi yathā ghaṭaḥ abhidheyaḥ prameya tvāt paṭa vat
translated: The purely positive reason has pervasion by positive concomitance only, like: the pot is expressible because it is knowable, like a cloth.

original: atra prameyatvābhidhyatvayor vyatirekavyāptir nāsti sarvasyāpi prameyatvād abhidheyatvāc ca /
analyzed: atra prameya tva abhidhya tvayoḥ vyatireka vyāptiḥ nā asti sarvasya api prameya tvāt abhidheya tvāt ca
translated: Here, there is no pervasion by negative concomitance between knowability and expressibility, because everything is knowable and expressible.

original: vyatirekamātravyāptikaṃ kevalavyatireki yathā pṛthivī tarebhyo bhidyate gandhavattvāt /
analyzed: vyatireka mātra vyāptikam kevala vyatireki yathā pṛthivī tarebhyaḥ bhidyate gandhavat tvāt
translated: The purely negative reason has pervasion by negative concomitance only, like: earth is different from water because it has smell.

original: yad itarebhyo na bhidyate na tad gandhavat /
analyzed: yat itarebhyaḥ na bhidyate na tat gandhavat
translated: What is not different from the others is not endowed with smell.

analyzed: yathā jalam
translated: Like water.

analyzed: na ca iyam tathā
translated: And this is not so.

original: tasmān na tatheti atra yad gandhavat tad itarabhinnam ity anvayadṛṣṭanto nāsti pṛthivīmātrasya pakṣatvāt //
analyzed: tasmāt na tathā iti atra yat gandhavat tat itara bhinnam iti anvaya dṛṣṭantaḥ na asti pṛthivī mātrasya pakṣa tvāt
translated: Therefore, it is not like that. Here, there is no positive example for the inference what is endowed with smell is different from the others because only earth is the subject.

analyzed: saṃdigdha sādhyavān pakṣaḥ
translated: The subject is doubtful with regard to the probandum.

analyzed: yathā dhūmavat tve hetau parvataḥ
translated: For example, in the case of the reason having smoke, the mountain.

analyzed: niścita sādhyavān sapakṣaḥ
translated: The positive example is ascertained to have the probandum.

analyzed: yathā tatra eva mahānasaḥ
translated: For example, in the same case, the kitchen.

analyzed: niścita sādhya abhāvavān vipakṣaḥ
translated: The negative example is ascertained to lack the probandum.

analyzed: yathā tatra eva mahā hradaḥ
translated: For example, in the same case, the great lake.

analyzed: savyabhicāra viruddha sat pakṣa asiddha bādhitāḥ pañca hetvābhāsāḥ
translated: The five fallacies of a reason are: the contradictory, the inconclusive, the unestablished, the over-exclusive, and the unestablished as a property of the subject.

analyzed: sa vyabhicāraḥ na aikāntikaḥ
translated: The contradictory is the inconclusive.

analyzed: sa trividhaḥ
translated: It is of three kinds.

analyzed: sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇa anupasaṃhāri bhedāt
translated: Because of being common, uncommon, and not a natural consequence.

analyzed: tatra sādhya abhāvavat vṛttiḥ sādhāraṇaḥ anaikāntikaḥ
translated: Among them, the common inconclusive is that which occurs in the absence of the probandum.

original: yathā parvato vahnimān prameyatvād iti prameyatvasya vahnyabhāvavati hrade vidyamānatvāt /
analyzed: yathā parvataḥ vahnimān prameya tvāt iti prameya tvasya vahni abhāvavati hrade vidyamāna tvāt
translated: For example, the mountain has fire because it is an object of knowledge, because being an object of knowledge exists in a lake that lacks fire.

analyzed: sarva sapakṣa vipakṣa vyāvṛttaḥ usādhāraṇaḥ
translated: The uncommon is that which is excluded from all similar instances and dissimilar instances.

analyzed: yathā śabdaḥ nityaḥ śabda tvāt iti
translated: Like: Sound is eternal, because it is sound.

original: śabdatvaṃ sarvebhyo nityebhyo'ntyebhyaś ca vyāvṛttaṃ śabdamātravṛtti /
analyzed: śabda tvam sarvebhyaḥ nityebhyaḥ antyebhyaḥ ca vyāvṛttam śabda mātra vṛtti
translated: Soundness is excluded from all eternals and non-eternals, and occurs only in sound.

analyzed: anvaya vyatireka dṛṣṭānta rahitaḥ nupasaṃhārī
translated: That which lacks a positive or negative example is inconclusive.

analyzed: yathā sarvam anityam prameya tvāt iti
translated: Like: Everything is non-eternal, because it is cognizable, like a pot.

analyzed: atra sarvasya api pakṣa tvāt dṛṣṭāntaḥ na asti
translated: Here, since everything is the subject, there is no example.

analyzed: sādhya abhāva vyāptaḥ hetuḥ viruddhaḥ
translated: A reason pervading the absence of the probandum is contradictory.

analyzed: yatra śabdaḥ nityaḥ kṛtaka tvāt iti
translated: Like: Sound is eternal, because it is produced, like a pot.

analyzed: kṛtaka tvam hi nitya tva abhāvena anitya tvena vyāptam
translated: For, being produced is pervaded by non-eternality, i.e., by non-eternality.

original: yasya sādhyabhāvasādhakaṃ hetvantaraṃ vidyate sa satpratipakṣaḥ /
analyzed: yasya sādhya bhāva sādhakam hetvantaram vidyate sa sat pratipakṣaḥ
translated: That which has another reason proving the absence of the probandum is counter-balanced.

original: yathā śabdo nityaḥ śrāvaṇatvāc chabdatvavad iti /
analyzed: yathā śabdaḥ nityaḥ śrāvaṇa tvāt śabda tva vat iti
translated: Like: Sound is eternal, because it is audible, like sound.

analyzed: śabdaḥ nityaḥ kārya tvāt ghaṭa vat iti
translated: Sound is non-eternal, because it is an effect, like a pot.
An unestablished [reason] is of three kinds.

analyzed: āśraya asiddhaḥ svarūpa asiddhaḥ vyāpya tva asiddhaḥ ca iti
translated: [It is] unestablished in the substratum, unestablished in its own form, and unestablished as a property of the subject.

original: āśrayāsiddho yathā gaganāravindaṃ surabhy aravindatvāt sarojāravindavat /
analyzed: āśraya asiddhaḥ yathā gagana aravindam surabhi aravinda tvāt saroja aravinda vat
translated: [An example of] an unestablished substratum is: The lotus in the sky is fragrant, because it is a lotus, like the lotus in a lake.

analyzed: atra gagana aravindam āśrayaḥ
translated: Here, the lotus in the sky is the substratum.

analyzed: sa ca na asti eva
translated: And that does not exist at all.

analyzed: svarūpa asiddhaḥ yathā śabdaḥ guṇaḥ cākṣuṣa tvāt
translated: An example of a reason that is not established with respect to its own nature is: Sound is a quality because it is visible.

original: atra cākṣuṣatvaṃ śabde nāsti śabdasya śrāvaṇatvāt /
analyzed: atra cākṣuṣa tvam śabde na asti śabdasya śrāvaṇa tvāt
translated: Here, visibility does not exist in sound, because sound is audible.

original: sopādhiko vyāpyatvāsiddhaḥ /🔽sādhyavyāpakatve sati sādhanāvyāpaka upādhiḥ /🔽sādhyasamānādhikaraṇātyantābhāvāpratiyogitvaṃ sādhyavyāpakatvam /
analyzed: sa upādhikaḥ vyāpya tva asiddhaḥ  sādhya vyāpaka tve sati sādhana avyāpakaḥ upādhiḥ  sādhya samāna adhikaraṇa atyanta abhāva apratiyogi tvam sādhya vyāpaka tvam
translated: One that has a counter-example is not established as the probandum.🔽A counter-example is a property that is co-extensive with the probandum but not with the reason.🔽Being the counter-example of an absolute absence that is co-extensive with the probandum is being co-extensive with the probandum.
Being the counter-example of a desired absolute absence that is present where the reason is present is not being co-extensive with the reason.

original: parvato dhūmavān vahnimattvād ity atrārdrendhasaṃyoga upādhiḥ /
analyzed: parvataḥ dhūmavān vahnimat tvāt iti atra ārdra indha saṃyogaḥ upādhiḥ
translated: In the inference The mountain has smoke because it has fire, the conjunction of wet fuel is a counter-example.

original: tathā hi /🔽yatra dhūmas tatrārdrendhnasaṃyoga iti sādhyavyāpakatā /
analyzed: tathā hi  yatra dhūmaḥ tatra ārdra indhna saṃyogaḥ iti sādhya vyāpaka tā
translated: This is because:🔽Wherever there is smoke, there is the conjunction of wet fuel, so it is co-extensive with the probandum.

analyzed: yatra vahniḥ tatra ārdra indhana saṃyoga abhāvāt iti sādhana avyāpaka tā
translated: Wherever there is fire, there is the absence of the conjunction of wet fuel, so it is not co-extensive with the reason.

analyzed: evam sādhya vyāpaka tve  sati sādhana avyāpaka tvāt ardra indhana saṃyogaḥ upādhiḥ
translated: Thus, being co-extensive with the probandum🔽but not co-extensive with the reason, the conjunction of wet fuel is a counter-example.

analyzed: sa upādhika tvāt vahnimat tvam vyāpya tva asiddham
translated: Because it has a counter-example, the presence of fire is not established as the probandum.

original: yasya sādhyābhāvaḥ pramāṇāntareṇa niścitaḥ sa bādhitaḥ /
analyzed: yasya sādhya abhāvaḥ pramāṇa antareṇa niścitaḥ sa bādhitaḥ
translated: One who has ascertained the absence of the probandum by another means of knowledge is contradicted.

analyzed: yathā vahniḥ anuṣṇaḥ dravya tvāt iti
translated: For example, fire is not hot, because it is a substance,

original: atrānuṣṇatvaṃ sādhyaṃ tadabhāva uṣṇatvaṃ spārśanapratyakṣeṇa gṛhyata iti bādhitatvam //
analyzed: atra anuṣṇa tvam sādhyam tad abhāve uṣṇa tvam spārśana pratyakṣeṇa gṛhyate iti bādhita tvam
translated: Here, not being hot is the probandum. Its absence, which is being hot, is grasped by tactile perception. Thus, it is contradicted.

analyzed: upamiti karaṇam upamānam
translated: Upamiti (analogy) is the means of knowing what is similar.

analyzed: saṃjñā saṃjñi saṃbandha jñānam upamitiḥ
translated: The knowledge of the relation between a name and its bearer is analogy.

analyzed: tad karaṇam sādṛśya jñānam
translated: The means of that is the knowledge of similarity.

analyzed: atideśa vākya artha smaraṇam avāntara vyāpāraḥ
translated: The recollection of the meaning of the text that teaches the analogy is an intermediate operation.

original: tathā hi kaś cid gavayaśabdārtham ajānan kutaś cid āraṇyakapuruṣād gosadṛśo gavaya iti śrutvā vanaṃ gato vākyārthaṃ smaran gosadṛṣaṃ piṇḍaṃ 🔽paśyati /
analyzed: tathā hi kaḥ cit gavaya śabda artham a jānan kutas cit āraṇyaka puruṣāt go sadṛśaḥ gavayaḥ iti śrutvā vanam gataḥ vākya artham smaran go sadṛṣam piṇḍam  paśyati
translated: For example, someone who does not know the meaning of the word gavaya, having heard from a certain forest-dweller that a gavaya is like a cow, goes to the forest, remembers the meaning of the sentence, and sees an individual that is like a cow.

original: tadanantaram asau gavayaśabdavācya ity upamitir utpadyte //
analyzed: tad anantaram asau gavaya śabda vācyaḥ iti upamitiḥ utpadyate
translated: Immediately after that, the cognition arises that this is what is denoted by the word gavaya.

analyzed: āpta vākyam śabdaḥ  āptaḥ tu yathārtha vaktā
translated: A statement by a reliable person is verbal testimony.🔽A reliable person is one who speaks in accordance with reality.

analyzed: vākyam pada samūhaḥ
translated: A statement is a collection of words.

analyzed: yathā gām ānaya iti
translated: For example, bring the cow.

analyzed: śaktam padam
translated: A word is capable.

original: asmāt padād ayam artho boddhavya itīśvarasaṃketaḥ śaktiḥ //
analyzed: asmāt padāt ayam arthaḥ boddhavyaḥ iti īśvara saṃketaḥ śaktiḥ
translated: The power is the Lord's intention that this meaning should be understood from this word.

analyzed: ākāṅkṣā yogya tā saṃnidhiḥ ca vākya artha jñāna hetuḥ
translated: Desire to know, fitness, and proximity are the causes of understanding the meaning of a sentence.
The non-indication of syntactical relation due to the exclusion of other words is expectancy.

analyzed: artha ābādhaḥ yogyatā  padānām avilambena uccāraṇam saṃnidhiḥ
translated: The absence of contradiction in meaning is fitness.🔽The utterance of words without delay is proximity.

analyzed: ākāṅkṣā ādi rahitam vākyam apramāṇam
translated: A sentence devoid of expectancy etc. is not a means of valid knowledge.

original: yathā gaur aśvaḥ puruṣo hastīti na pramāṇam ākāṅkṣāvirahāt /
analyzed: yathā gauḥ aśvaḥ puruṣaḥ hastī iti na pramāṇam ākāṅkṣā virahāt
translated: For example, cow, horse, man, elephant is not a means of valid knowledge, because of the absence of expectancy.

original: agninā siñced iti na pramāṇaṃ yogyatāvirahāt /
analyzed: agninā siñcet iti na pramāṇam yogya tā virahāt
translated: One should sprinkle with fire is not a means of valid knowledge, because of the absence of fitness.

original: prahare prehare'sahoccāritāni gām ānayetyādipadāni na pramāṇaṃ saṃnidhyabhāvāt //
analyzed: prahare prehare saha uccāritāni gām ānaya ityādi padāni na pramāṇam saṃnidhi abhāvāt
translated: Words such as bring the cow uttered simultaneously in different places are not a means of valid knowledge, because of the absence of proximity.

analyzed: vākyam dvividham
translated: A sentence is of two kinds.

analyzed: vaidikam laukikam ca
translated: Vedic and secular.

analyzed: vaidikam īśvara ukta tvāt sarvam eva pramāṇam
translated: All Vedic sentences are means of valid knowledge because they are uttered by God.

analyzed: laukikam tu āpta uktam pramāṇam
translated: But secular sentences uttered by a trustworthy person are means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: anyat a pramāṇam
translated: Others are not means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: vākya artha jñānam śabda jñānam
translated: The knowledge of the meaning of a sentence is the knowledge of words.

analyzed: tad karaṇam śabdaḥ
translated: That which brings about that is a word.
False experience is of three kinds, due to the difference of doubt, error and reasoning.

analyzed: ekasmin dharmini viruddha nānā dharma vaiśiṣṭya avagāhi jñānam saṃśayaḥ
translated: Knowledge that comprehends the possession of mutually contradictory properties in a single substratum is doubt.

analyzed: yathā sthāṇuḥ vā purṣaḥ vā iti
translated: For example, Is it a post or a man?

analyzed: mithyā jñānam viparyayaḥ
translated: False knowledge is error.

analyzed: yathā śuktau idam rajatam iti
translated: For example, This is silver in a shell.

original: vyāpyāropeṇa vyāpakāropas tarkaḥ yathā yadi vahnir na syāt tarhi dhūmo'pi na syād iti //
analyzed: vyāpya āropeṇa vyāpaka āropaḥ tarkaḥ yathā yadi vahniḥ na syāt tarhi dhūmaḥ api na syāt iti
translated: Inference is the assumption of the pervader by the assumption of the pervaded, like If fire were not to exist, then smoke would not exist either.

original: smṛtir api dvividhā /🔽yathārthāyathārthā ca pramājanyā yathārthā /
analyzed: smṛtiḥ api dvividhā  yathārthā ayathārthā ca pramā janyā yathārthā
translated: Memory is also of two kinds.🔽The one that arises from valid knowledge is true.

analyzed: apramā ajanyā ayathārthā
translated: The one that arises from invalid knowledge is false.

analyzed: sarva īśām anukūla tayā vedanīyam sukham
translated: Pleasure is to be experienced favorably by all.

analyzed: sarva īśām pratikūla tayā vedanīyam duḥkham
translated: Pain is to be experienced unfavorably by all.

analyzed: icchā kāmaḥ
translated: Desire is will.

analyzed: krodhaḥ dveṣaḥ  kṛtiḥ prayatnaḥ  vihita karma janyaḥ dharmaḥ
translated: Anger is hatred.🔽Effort is exertion.🔽Dharma arises from enjoined action.

analyzed: niṣiddha karma janyaḥ tu adharmaḥ
translated: Adharma, on the other hand, arises from prohibited action.

analyzed: buddhi ādayaḥ aṣṭa ātma mātra viśeṣa guṇāḥ
translated: The eight beginning with intellect are qualities specific to the self alone.

analyzed: buddhi icchā prayatnāḥ dvividhāḥ
translated: Intellect, will, and effort are of two kinds.

analyzed: nityāḥ anityāḥ ca
translated: They are eternal and non-eternal.

analyzed: nityā īśvarasya
translated: The eternal ones belong to God.

analyzed: anityāḥ jīvasya
translated: The non-eternal ones belong to the individual soul.

analyzed: saṃskāraḥ trividhaḥ
translated: Impression is of three kinds.

analyzed: vegaḥ bhāvanā sthiti sthāpakaḥ ca iti
translated: Velocity, impression, and that which stabilizes stability.

analyzed: vegaḥ pṛthivī ādi catuṣṭaya manaḥ vṛttiḥ
translated: Velocity is the activity of the four beginning with earth and the mind.

analyzed: anubhava janyā smṛti hetuḥ bhāvanā ātma mātra vṛttiḥ
translated: Impression, which is the cause of memory arising from experience, is an activity of the self alone.

original: anyathā kṛtasya punas tadavasthāpādakaḥ sthitisthāpakaḥ kaṭādipṛthivīvṛttiḥ //
analyzed: anyathā kṛtasya punar tad avasthā āpādakaḥ sthiti sthāpakaḥ kaṭa ādi pṛthivī vṛttiḥ
translated: The 'maintainer' is that which restores to its former state what has been otherwise affected, and it inheres in earth, such as a pot, etc.

analyzed: calana ātmakam karma  ūrdhva deśa saṃyoga hetuḥ utkṣepaṇam
translated: Action is of the nature of motion.🔽'Upward throwing' is the cause of conjunction with a higher place.

analyzed: adhas deśa saṃyoga hetuḥ apakṣepaṇam  śarīra saṃnikṛṣṭa saṃyoga hetuḥ ākuñcanam
translated: 'Downward throwing' is the cause of conjunction with a lower place.🔽'Contraction' is the cause of conjunction with what is near the body.

analyzed: viprakṛṣṭa saṃyoga hetuḥ prasāraṇam
translated: 'Expansion' is the cause of conjunction with what is distant.

analyzed: anyat sarvam gamanam
translated: All other [actions] are 'motion'.
It inheres in the four, earth, etc., and the mind alone.

analyzed: nityam ekam aneka anugatam sāmānyam
translated: The universal is eternal, one, and inheres in many.

analyzed: dravya guṇa karma vṛtti
translated: It inheres in substance, quality, and action.

analyzed: tat dvividham para apara bhedāt
translated: It is of two kinds, as divided into 'supreme' and 'inferior'.

analyzed: param sattā
translated: The 'supreme' is existence.

analyzed: aparam dravya tva ādiḥ
translated: The 'inferior' is substance-ness, etc.
The 'particulars' inhere in eternal substances, and distinguish [them].

analyzed: nitya saṃbandhaḥ samavāyaḥ
translated: Inherence is eternal relation.
It inheres in what is not produced simultaneously.

original: yayor dvayor madhya ekam avinaśyadaparāśritam evāvatiṣṭate tāv ayutasiddau /
analyzed: yayoḥ dvayoḥ madhye ekam a vinaśyat apara āśritam eva avatiṣṭate tau ayuta siddau
translated: Those two of which one remains without being destroyed and without depending on another are 'not produced simultaneously'.

original: yathāvayavāvayavinau guṇaguṇinau kriyākriyāvantau jātivyaktī viśeṣanityadravye ceti //
analyzed: yathā avayava avayavinau guṇa guṇinau kriyā akriyāvantau jāti vyaktī viśeṣa nitya dravye ca iti
translated: For example, the parts and the whole, the quality and the qualified, the action and the active, the species and the individual, and the particular and the eternal substance.

analyzed: anādiḥ sa antaḥ prāgabhāvaḥ
translated: The prior non-existence is beginningless and has an end.

analyzed: utpatteḥ pūrvam kāryasya
translated: Prior to its origination, of the effect.

analyzed: sa ādiḥ anantaḥ pradhvaṃsaḥ
translated: The beginningless and endless destruction.

analyzed: utpatti anantaram kāryasya
translated: After the origination, of the effect.

analyzed: traikālika saṃsarga avacchinna pratiyogitāka utyanta abhāvaḥ
translated: The absolute negation, which is delimited by the relation of inherence with the object existing in all the three times.

analyzed: yathā bhū tale ghaṭaḥ na asti iti
translated: As for example, there is no jar on the ground.

analyzed: tādātmya saṃbandha avacchinna pratiyogitākaḥ anyonyābhāvaḥ yathā ghaṭaḥ paṭaḥ na bhavati iti
translated: The mutual negation, which is delimited by the relation of identity, as for example, the jar is not a cloth.

original: sarveṣāṃ padārthānāṃ yathāyatham ukteṣv antarbhāvāt saptaiva padārthā iti siddham //
analyzed: sarveṣām padārthānām yathāyatham ukteṣu antarbhāvāt sapta eva padārthāḥ iti siddham
translated: Thus, it is established that there are only seven categories, since all the objects are included in the above-mentioned categories as appropriate.
For the easy understanding of the doctrines of Kanada and Nyaya by the young,
the learned Annambhatta has composed the Tarka Sangraha.
